Id. ¶130.  Plaintiffs allege they refused a $10,000,000 demand.  Id. ¶¶131 and 134.  They
allege Shurka retaliated against Plaintiffs via three tortious communications on November 14,
2024 and January 14, 2024.  Id. ¶¶135, 142, and 160.
III. ANTI-SLAPP STATEMENT OF FACTS
A. Michael’s Public Description of Her Education and Experience
Shurka learned of an organization operating in the wellness field called Energy
Enhancement Systems, LLC (“EES”) because its product had helped his family.  Ex. B, ...

(unpublished disposition) (“. . . Meadows’ argument that the statements were not made in
good faith because evidence shows Shepherd made the statements ‘in an attempt to extort money
from him’ fails because it misconstrues the meaning of good faith here.  Good faith in the anti-
SLAPP context only asks whether a preponderance of the evidence supports that the statements
were true or made without knowledge that the statements were untrue.”).  UNIFYD Inc. therefore
has met its burden under the goo...

Plaintiffs Cannot Meet Their Burden Under Step 2
The second step in an Anti-SLAPP analysis requires the Court to consider whether the
Plaintiffs can meet their burden to demonstrate that their claims have minimal merit.  Lazer, 137
Nev. at 442, 495 P.3d at 442.  Minimal merit means that a plaintiff must demonstrate “with prima
facie evidence” that he is likely to prevail on his claims.  See NRS 41.660.  Plaintiffs cannot meet
their burden on step 2 in this case.
